nodes.text: Intergenerational economic mobility in the United States varies systematically with geography; local area characteristics help explain differences in upward mobility across places
At the national level the conditional expectation of a child's income rank given parent income rank is approximately linear (rank-rank relationship)
The canonical log-log intergenerational income elasticity (IGE) is unstable in these data because the log-log relation is nonlinear and sensitive to zero or small incomes

Intergenerational mobility varies substantially across commuting zones (CZs): both relative mobility (rank-rank slope) and absolute upward mobility (expected child rank for parents at p=25) show large spatial variation

Five area-level factors are strongly correlated with upward mobility: (i) residential segregation, (ii) income inequality (bottom 99% Gini), (iii) K–12 school quality (test scores/dropout residuals), (iv) social capital, and (v) family stability (fraction single parents)

Method: Construct national sample from deidentified federal tax records (1996–2012) linking >40 million children to parents; measure parent mean family income 1996–2000, child mean family income 2011–2012, assign children to CZ where grew up using ZIP at first dependent claim

Evidence/Result: National rank-rank slope estimate is 0.341 (a 10 percentile increase in parent rank implies ~3.41 percentile increase in child rank); rank-rank relation is highly linear and robust across specifications

Evidence/Result: Intermediate outcomes are linearly related to parent rank: a 10 percentile increase in parent rank associates with a 6.7 percentage point increase in college attendance and a 3 percentage point decrease in female teenage birth rate

Evidence/Result: CZ magnitudes — examples: absolute upward mobility (mean child rank for parents at 25th percentile) ranges from 35.8 (Charlotte) to 46.2 (Salt Lake City) among large CZs; P(bottom quintile parent -> top quintile child) ranges from 4.4% (Charlotte) to 12.9% (San Jose)

Evidence: Cross-CZ correlations show lower upward mobility where (i) racial segregation and income segregation (especially segregation of poverty) are higher, (ii) bottom-99% inequality is higher, (iii) school test scores/dropout residuals are worse, (iv) social capital measures are lower, and (v) single-parent share is higher

Robustness/Methodological results: rank-rank estimates are robust to life-cycle and attenuation bias if child income is measured after age 30 and parent income averaged over multiple years; rank-rank is more stable than IGE across specifications

Conclusion: Geography matters for economic opportunity—children's prospects depend heavily on where they grow up; place-based differences account for substantial variation in expected child ranks, comparable to sizable fractions of parental income effects

Limitation: Analysis is descriptive and correlational—cross-sectional CZ correlations cannot be interpreted as causal; many covariates are endogenous and further causal research is required (follow-up work studies causal effects of place using moves)
